Inspector Lewis spin-off from the Inspector Morse series was a good show itself. Lewis is not as self-absorbed or socially antagonist as his former DI. By the 7th season, he is getting old himself, and his partner in the show is perhaps being groomed to assume the post. It's old style British procedural in Oxford, and the partner is equally over-educated as Morse was. Honorable men who quietly go about seeking the miscreants of nefarious murders in a seemingly idyllic intellectual community in the old style, not overly reliant on forensics. I really enjoy the background music which sets the mood for this series, by Barrington Pheloung. That's how much I like it, I've never paid much attention to background composers of tv shows. After Inspector Morse disappeared from the steaming network this summer, I decided to buy the Inspector Lewis series. Both still entertain me. I barely watch contemporary regular tv anymore, so streaming these series as often as I like is very much appreciated.

I loved Inspector Morse and now that Lewis is the boss he's absorbed the sleuthing chops of his mentor. He also has his own sergeant now, James Hathaway. Hathaway is Cambridge-educated (Morse was Oxford-educated) and picks up the thread of erudite quotations and musings that Morse was so famous for. Hathaway also Lewis' more posh, better-educated emissary to the dons in the ivory tower that are often enmeshed in their murder investigations. Lewis, though, is more human, more vulnerable, and yet somehow tougher than Morse ever was. He's a widower and he has children and he is moored to the world in the way that makes Lewis an even richer show than Morse. I was so bummed when I ran through season 7. I hope we get one more season.

I highly recommend this series to anyone who like detective stories.  Since this is a take-off of the Inspector Morse series, I can see the influence.  Throughout the Inspector Lewis series, he knows he has come into his own and he values the lessons he learned when Morse was his mentor.  He now mentors his own sergeant (Hathaway) with that same care and respect.  In series 7, Lewis made himself believe it was time to putter in his garden and make a life with the pathologist giving him an arms length existence from the world of detection.  However, his old team realizes they need him and he finds that he is being pulled back into the arena of crime solving.  He pretends to not really want to do it but he doesnt do things by halves and it is obvious he is happy to be back.  Gingerly he steps into the role of consultant and tries to be sensitive to Hathaways position.  This is not an easy task and he does blunder a bit but as he said, the thing he likes most about that job is that you never stop learning.  Hathaway has also been experiencing some growing pains. Do I recommend this series?  Oh yes, You need to watch series 1-7.  The characters draw you in and you feel you are part of what they are doing and thinking.  They never let you know who the bad buy is until the end, even in the last episode, "Beyond Good and Evil", there is a twist.  I was sad to hear that series 7 was the last it was like saying goodbye to an old friend.  I'm hearing rumors of a new series, fingers crossed!

This continuation of the Inspector Morse Mysteries is superior, in my opinion.  Inspector Lewis brings a practicum of procedure and his erudite sergeant  brings a tangent of the Oxford braininess that marries into an effective team worthy of of the Morse legacy. Season 7 finds Lewis retired and happy with his new life, but just when he thinks he's out... they pull him back in!

Inspector Lewis is retired and Hathaway has been promoted to DI. One certainly gets the impression that Lewis bored but refuses to admit it. Hathaway has a problem giving his subordinate Sergeants tasks and responsibilities. His first Sergeant requested a transfer and his second one DS Lizzie Maddox is in the process of transferring as well.

It seems that the Oxford police need more manpower and Innocent uses that situation as an excuse to bring back DI Lewis. She adds him to Hathaway' s team.

There is a bit of tension at first, each wondering what their roles will be in this threesome. Lewis starts giving Maddox more responsibility and as times passes and Hathaway sees her worth, he also begins to trust her more.

The addition of Maddox works well and is seamless. The acting, as usual is first-rate and the stories are all good, although, my favorite is the last, "Beyond Good and Evil", which also happens to be a title of a Nietzsche book and his ideas do figure prominently though they are not overbearing.

In all a wonderful return and great new dynamic between Lewis and Hathaway. I hope this series is not the end of Lewis and Hathaway.

Seasons 1-6
Inspector Morse is older (just beyond middle age), Oxford educated and specifically erudite of opera, which he loved, irritating (of his own intolerance) "old fashioned,"often self-centered, arrogant, even to his own division and others, unmarried, and often rebellious of procedural protocol, irritating most of his co-workers. His work,his profession, was all he had, and was his only life, success. He drank beer on the job as he pleased, always trying to coax Lewis into the same. In his staunch attitude of perfection, doing it his way (the better way), he did not often give credit to his underling partner, detective Lewis, who in his occasional brilliance of critical clues, helped him solve some hard cases. He was kept on because of his "preciseness" of logical skills which gave him much success and was a loner, both in his profession and personal life.
When detective Lewis wanted to move up, Morse, seemingly jealous (of his "youth), did not encourage Lewis to take the Inspector exam when he was willing and ready (a strong push from his wife) but then finally does, upon finding out about his medical diagnosis, of which he then decides to retire.
It was Morse's depth of character in his own fallible character traits and personality that drew me to this series. He could not see his own frustrating loneliness and frailty of which he most often judged in the commonness of most others, as either being incompetent, lacking vision, unwilling to strive for more knowledge (which expands and is power itself), or just less able, precisely so, as he would say, missing the greater, due to their superficial minds, attitudes, choice of profession in their lower commonality in life, themselves, while struggling internally with some of the same,  of his own "falling short" of his own expectations, and not having found a compatible (or commit worthy) companion.

In 7, (combining the UK series 7, 8) in agreement with another reviewer, I also found it somewhat slower, and lighter of character compared with Morse's character. In season 7 (the first disk), some of the story details of Lewis' attitude and future personal decision shadow Morse's, though Inspector Lewis is mostly in contrast to Morse, excepting times when he verbalizes some of his own (Morse's?) arrogance of his experience, knowledge and position. His very young, inexperienced partner detective, Hathaway, is irritated with this, using subtler, more personal ways, strategies to deal with others, especially those not too far from his age. Lewis has a personal irritation that Hathaway is even younger than he was when he joined with Morse (as Morse felt about him) and who and is also Oxford educated (somewhat intimidating for Lewis).
Lewis is less analytical (and less educated) than Morse was, coming from a more common background, following in the footsteps of many of his peers, who's fathers and back, were policemen and is a team player. He is more inter-personally and socially adept at relationships, lighter of personal being, seeing life and people from a horizontal, plain, view. He works hard and to eventually climb up, (he shows respect and comraderie for his fellow policemen and so is much liked and respected himself), and yet chooses to challenge himself to learn from Morse how to be more precisely observant, and so, see more deliberately, unseen clues, to better his skills and himself. He has even pushed himself to learn about, to become, just a little bit more educated about the classical arts (literature, music). He also gets involved with the pathologist, Dr. Laura Dobson, who was also interested in Morse, who had a fear of intimacy, commitment, so it never progressed.  But in Lewis' case, they go forward from friends to "couple" and move in together and are content, as he retires, yet comes back part-time (not compatible to Laura) to solve some hard cases and one that will challenge him from his beginning years.
On disk 2, enter detective Hathaway, soon to be Inspector Hathaway, who is less confident about himself, (Morse had his music and beer Hathaway has literature, art, his smokes-incessantly, and then tries to quit)  his line of work, and secretive about his personal life, seeming to be internally searching for something more humanely uplifting, giving him more challenge, responsibility, power, as Lewis emphasizes his experience, knowledge and position, when Hathaway seems to crowd him or find clues he misses. He is also Oxford educated (intimidating for Lewis) but not boastful of it. He is almost as alone as Morse was, yet more intellectually engrossed in other things. He shows a personal experience and strength for younger people, as lost as he is internally. He resents Lewis' attitude, resentment (which Lewis does eventually reveal) though sometimes sees clear about it, yet it pushes him for change. Nevertheless, he is unsure of his future expectations, not shaped yet, though wanting a stronger, defined identity. When he reveals to Lewis that he wants to try for the upgrade to Inspector, Lewis does as Morse did, and tries to put him off, as he himself is serious about retirement, telling Hathaway he needs more time, as Hathaway then reveals he wants to leave. But he doesn't, Lewis encourages him, he goes forward and becomes the next in line of Inspectors.
In some ways, the mystery of Hathaway reminds me of Morse's internal dialogue, but from a wider perspective (being younger, more aware), and yet quietly, with some of Morse's own questions about the lack of sanctity of life:  darkness of life, cavalier thinking about oneself, others, degradation of values, and greatest, death and specifically, young death. While Morse whined, Lewis questioned emotionally, and now Hathaway tries to face and accept. I hope there will be a season 8 (9)!

I love Lewis...everything about this series is quality--from the writing to the acting to the City of Oxford itself.  Whately is masterful as the moral, kind Everyman, Lewis, and Laurence Fox is his perfect foil as the enigmatic, slightly overly intellectual Hathaway.  These two actors are effortless and completely believable filling their characters' shoes.  Angela Griffin is a nice addition, too, and is carefully written so that she adds depth, but doesn't interfere with the Lewis/Hathaway long-term bromance.  And I'm glad they finally got Lewis and Hobson together--although that relationship, while "old shoe" comfortable, seems unnaturally and unnecessarily superficial.  Maybe that's just the famous British reserve.
A great part of what makes this series work is relationship--Lewis with Hathaway, Lewis with Hobson, Lewis and Hathaway with Innocent (I was very sorry to hear they have ditched Rebecca Front in the upcoming new season) and Maddox--and the main characters' unflagging moral compass.  Yet the series writers seem reluctant to lay bare much of what makes their main characters tick--their back stories and their feelings.  They give all the depth to the characters and chaos du jour, rather than to those who drive the series.
The Lewis plots are convoluted and byzantine, the backdrops, music and cinematography are always gorgeous and DI Lewis, DI Hathaway, Doctor Hobson, CS Innocent and DS Maddox are easy folks to like.  Series 7 is more of the same good "who-dunit" genre in the style of "Morse" and its prequel, "Endeavour." Unlike many of the shoot-em up, car chase, blood-drenched American cop shows, "Inspector Lewis" is intelligent, engaging and a pleasant way to spend some down time.  I'm always pleased to return to Oxford and visit again with my favorite peace-keepers--although given what must be an outrageous murder rate for a city Oxford's size, I'm not sure I'd live in that beautiful old university town.

Season 7 has a slightly different premise: Detective Inspector Lewis, having retired, comes back to work part-time to help his former sergeant, James Hathaway, adjust to being a DI with a sergeant of his own.  Hathaway's sergeant, a young woman of color, is an interesting and enjoyable character in her own right and a welcome addition to the show. The deep personal connection between Hathaway and Lewis is not really a feature in this season, particularly because Hathaway is initially less than thrilled at Lewis's return, but enough of the original elements -- great chemistry and writing -- are there for long-term fans, like myself, to enjoy this new variant.  It is a bittersweet but also happy continuation of the series, particularly after the ending of Season 6, when it seemed as though there would be no more episodes of Lewis. First, an important note. There are - as I post this review - almost 300 reviews posted for this release.  Since it was not released by PBS Home Video until November 2014 all the other reviews are probably based on the US Broadcast Version. So when reading reviews before November I would suggest taking that into consideration. I see there are comments about editing. The PBS BD contains the original UK episodes which run about 93 minutes each. Since PBS airings are usually 85 minutes - allowing stations to promote other shows and provide sponsorship intros - that means about eight minutes has been excised. Since I did not see the TV versions, I can't tell what was cut. It was not for sex or strong language (neither of which is here) so it may be violence.

As for the three stories here, I enjoyed the relationship among the police officers but I found the stories fairly confusing with way too many suspects (especially in the second story). The original series was based on the Inspector Morse novels by Colin Dexter. These stories are newly written and only based on the characters, in order to use the Morse and Lewis names for merchandising. So, yes, I enjoyed watching the three stories here (2 are on disc one and one on disc two) but I can't say I loved them.

There are no special features on the BD set.

I hope you found this review both informative and helpful.

Steve Ramm

"Inspector Lewis Season 7" actually finds DI Robbie Lewis (Kevin Whately) retired. James Hathaway (Laurence Fox) has been promoted to DI and has a new partner, DS Lizzie Maddox (Angela Griffin). The series is getting away from its tradition of plots that revolve around the academic community at Oxford University. One episode features Oxford prominently; another integrates one university professor; and the other ignores Oxford entirely. James Hathaway has lost some appeal, as he no longer seems to be a fish out of water in the police department. DS Lizzie Maddox is hard-working and working-class. She's a good character but suffers from being a token female, added for no reason except to have a female detective in the field. DCS Jean Innocent (Rebecca Front) is still the boss. Dr. Laura Hobson (Clare Holman) is still the police pathologist. The mysteries are entertaining enough, but, in "Entry Wounds" and "The Lions of Nemea", the tangled relationships between the characters overshadow the murder mysteries. The PBS Shop claims that this DVD contains the full UK versions, which would be 360 minutes. But it also says that this DVD is 270 minutes long, which would be the US versions. So we have ourselves another mystery.

"Entry Wounds" begins as a retired DI Robbie Lewis is living with Dr. Laura Hobson, the police department pathologist, and tinkering in his backyard. James Hathaway has been promoted to Inspector following a pilgrimage to Spain, and he's been assigned a new partner, DS Lizzie Maddox. Lewis is coaxed out of retirement by DCS Innocent to alleviate the department's staffing problems just after a hunting lodge owned by Tom Marston (Aden Gillett) is burned to the ground.  Marston has been receiving threatening messages from animal rights activists. Then his business partner Dr. Alastair Stoke (Jonny Phillips), a neurosurgeon, is murdered on the grounds. Gillian Fernsby (Anna Carteret), wife of the lodge's former owner, is the mother of Lorraine (Elizabeth Rider), Dr. Stoke's faithful nurse. Junior surgeon Simon Eastwood (Leo Staar) has accused Stoke of misconduct when a young patient was permanently disabled in surgery. Deciphering the relationships between characters somewhat overwhelms the murder mystery.

"The Lions of Nemea" finds DI Lewis ensconced comfortably back in his old position and working side by side with Hathaway, while DS Maddox does a lot of the spade work. An American classics student, Rose Anderson (Alisha Bailey), is stabbed to death on her evening run after having a big argument with her roommate Chlo (Jessica Henwick) over Chlo's boyfriend Harrison (Michael Ryan). Rose had recently had an acrimonious breakup with an older married physics professor, Felix Garwood (John Light), the husband of the professor handling her thesis, Phillippa Garwood (Andrea Lowe) and uncle of young Tabitha (Kitty Rich), a seriously ill child Rose was tutoring so that she might keep up in school. Rose's research revolved around a Victorian translation of a lost Euripedes play that had been unearthed by Professor Simon Flaxmore (Clive Merrison), who claims never to have met her. Again, we have an unlikely tangle of relationships that take more effort to unravel than the murder mystery does.

Graham Lawrie (Alec Newman) was convicted of the murders of 3 police officers 13 years ago, but his conviction may be overturned on appeal in a matter of days in "Beyond Good and Evil". Lewis is irate, as he was the investigating detective on the Lawrie case. As the detectives brace themselves for the appeal, someone calls 999 to report a jumper on one of Oxford University's towers. PC Mark Travis (Gruffudd Glyn) responds...and is struck down with a sharp instrument resembling the roof slater's hammer that Lawrie allegedly used. Did police and prosecutors get the wrong man all those years ago? Did Lawrie have an accomplice? Or is someone trying to make it look like Lawrie is innocent in anticipation of his appeal? Lewis, Hathaway and Maddox makes the rounds of Lawrie's psychiatrist Dr. Sally Rook (Susan Wooldridge), his solicitor Katherine Warrick (Priyanga Burford), his tutor in nihilism, Oxford professor Brendon Ward (Tom Davey), and smitten supporter Pamela Carson (Robin Weaver) to find the killer.

The boys are back!  And, more human than ever.

Lewis is softer, as he "takes a break from retirement."  Hathaway is complex as ever, with an obvious internal storm which we will never know.  But in this series, unlike the others, they are now personal friends above all else.  Can you imagine Hathaway saying "Robbie?"  Well, he does.  :)

This season, there is also a great crowd of wonderful women:  Innocent is a bit softer too, and Laura is now a significant other, rather than an unspoken flirtation at work.  She is really beautiful and warm.  And, there is the new sergeant!  I forget her name, (she is such a new character,) but she is Hathaway's second in command.  Well portrayed and a pleasure to watch.

The cast of featured characters in the mysteries is stellar as always, and completely takes the audience into the rabbit hole.  That, the writing, the music, the cinematography, and the overall sense of perfection of this series which has kept this series at such a high level of excellence, continues in season 7.  This season offers, as a bonus, an air of sentimental payoff for its long-term fans.

This is a conditional one star review. The original UK version of the series is 360 minutes for the three two hour episodes. It will be available from Amazon. UK on Nov. 17. If this version is 360 minutes long, then the one star review will be changed to a five star review. If it is the horribly chopped up version shown on PBS with each episode cut from 120 minutes to about 80 minutes, then this review will stay a one star and I strongly advise everyone to avoid this DVD like the crap it is and instead go buy the one from the UK. Since Amazon doesn't list the time on this release, I can only assume it's going to be the cut version from PBS, and hence the one star review. If Amazon adds the time and it is 360 minutes, then I'll change the review, but till they do, or somebody buys this and reports back that it is the 360 minute version, the rating will stay at one star. And don't be thrown off by the series number. This is actually series 8 in the UK, but PBS combined two series for some reason and so calls this series 7.

UPDATE: I got a post from a UK viewer and he said they are shown in the UK as six 1 hour shows, but with ads, so the actual running time is much less than the six one hour time slots would imply. I also noticed that Amazon has added a time for the series at 270 minutes, roughly 90 minutes an episode, which also ties into the PBS broadcast of the series in three 90 minute time slots. Since PBS typically only edits out about ten minutes from the shows, that also matches up with 90 minute original episodes. Due to this new information, I'm changing my review to five stars based on the content of the show now that the time discrepancies have been resolved.
